title: Centenary Way Yorkshire Walking Route

images.title: John Clive Nicholson, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Centenary Way or Yorkshire Wolds Way. Three quarters of a mile to Wharram le Street the sign reads.

images.title: Oliver Dixon / Wolds Way, Camp Dale
images.caption: Camp Dale, west of Hunmanby A particularly remote corner of the Yorkshire Wolds

images.title: Peter Church / The Centenary Way and the River Derwent
images.caption: The Centenary Way and the River Derwent

images.title: Peter Church / Footpath to the Jeffry Bog Plantation
images.caption: Footpath to the Jeffry Bog Plantation. The footpath is seen crossing a drainage ditch en route to the plantation. It runs alongside the river Derwent, and on the north side of the river is the Scarborough - York railway line. The Jeffry Bog Plantation is a Nature Reserve run by the Yorkshire Wildlife Trust.

images.title: Steve Serowka / The Hall Kirkham
images.caption: The Hall Kirkham. View from the Centenary Way footpath between Castle Howard Station and Kirkham Priory.

images.title: Steve Serowka / York to Scarborough Railway
images.caption: York to Scarborough Railway

images.title: Roger Gilbertson / Looking North To Ryedale
images.caption: Looking North To Ryedale. From the Centenary Way on the ridge of the Howardian Hills

images.title: West Flotmanby from the Centenary Way by Tracey Anne Taylor, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: West Flotmanby from the Centenary Way

description: Explore the Howardian Hills and the Yorkshire Wolds on this splendid walk devised to celebrate the 100th anniversary of Yorkshire County Council. The walk starts at the fabulous York Minster next to the Roman York Walls in the historic city. It then runs all the way to Filey Brigg on the Yorkshire coast. The walk includes:

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: The Grapes Inn in Slingsby is a good place for a pit stop on the walk. The historic pub dates back to 1759 and is Grade II listed. There's a cosy interior with two log fires and a nice garden area outside. Food is of a high quality and includes excellent pizzas from the wood-fired pizzeria. The pub can be found on Railway St, YO62 4AL.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: The route is coincident with the Yorkshire Wolds Way for part of the trail. You could pick it up around Wharram Percy for example.
